biogHist.abstract: The Australian Aboriginal Evangelical Mission (AAEM) Hostel in Esperance, Western Australia was established in 1966 to provide accommodation, supervision and full board for Aboriginal boys aged 15 years and older who were working in the district. It was open until at least 1980.
biogHist.p: The Australian Aboriginal Evangelical Mission (AAEM) Hostel was largely independent of the Department of Native Welfare, but some financial assistance was received for particular building projects. It appears that the hostel was run by Mr John Pedlar for some years, possibly from 1966. It is not known how long Mr Pedlar ran the hostel, but it was likely to have been until at least into the 1970s, when he went up to Kalgoorlie to run the Millen Street Hostel. The AAEM Hostel continued until at least 1980.
Boys who lived at AAEM were aged over 15 years. It is possible that some boys were wards of the State.

During the 1970s, the boys were able to learn panel-beating, spray-painting, welding and mechanical skills at the Boys Training Workshop that had been established in Esperance by the superintendent of the Fairhaven Hostel. Some young men completed apprenticeships there. The young people at the Fairhaven Hostel, Condingup Hostel and the AAEM Hostel socialised regularly in Esperance.

chronItem.event: Location - The Australian Aboriginal Evangelical Mission Hostel was located in Esperance

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection (1894 - )
Department of Aboriginal Affairs [predecessors], Records, Department of Aboriginal Affairs (1886 - 2004)
Liaison - Australian Aborigines - Evangelical Mission Inc Esperance Hostel (1962 - 1978)
Department of Native Welfare, State of Western Australia (1955 - 1972)

descriptiveNote.p: The Australian Aboriginal Evangelical Mission Hostel received financial assistance from the Department of Native Welfare.
Millen Street Hostel was managed by John Pedlar, who had also managed the AAEM Hostel at Esperance from around 1966.

The superintendent of Fairhaven Hostel established a Boys Training Workshop which was attended by boys from the Australian Aboriginal Evangelical Mission Hostel, who also socialised regularly with Fairhaven residents.

Young men from the Australian Aboriginal Evangelical Mission Hostel and the Condingup Hostel socialised regularly in Esperance while Condingup was managed by the Churches of Churches of Christ Federal Aborigines Mission Board (Inc.), and it is possible that some Condingup residents went to live at the AAEM Hostel in Esperance when Condingup closed.

archref.abstract: 'Churches of Christ 'Fairhaven' Hostel, Esperance' is a history of the Churches of Christ's management of Fairhaven. It was written by Deslee Moyle, who has preserved many archival records relating to the Churches of Christ Federal Aborigines Mission Board (CCFAMB) and the organisation that followed it, the Australian Churches of Christ Indigenous Ministries (ACCIM). The item gives insight into life at Fairhaven and associated church activities in Esperance. The item also mentions the AAEM Hostel, Esperance; Condingup (Working Boys' Hostel); Norseman Mission, Cundeelee, and Wongutha.
